posts.summary: 48 books by Indigenous writers to read to understand residential schools | CBC Books
posts.body:
Here is a curated list of dozens of books by Indigenous writers about residential schools curated by Winnipeg-based Cree author David A. Robertson (@DaveAlexRoberts on Twitter).

48 books by Indigenous writers to read to understand residential schools | CBC Books

Here is the bare list, but be sure to check the link to read summaries, commentaries, and more links! General warning for the trauma and racism of residential schools, but these books cover most age groups, including children’s books.

1. Indian Horse by Richard Wagamese
2. The Orange Shirt Story & Phyllis’s Orange Shirt, both written by Phyllis Webstad, illustrated by Brock Nicol
3. Shi-shi-etko by Nicola I. Campbell, illustrated by Kim LaFave
4. Shin-chi’s Canoe by Nicola I. Campbell, illustrated by Kim LaFave
5. My Name is Seepeetza by Shirley Sterling
6. Seven Fallen Feathers by Tanya Talaga
7. Dear Canada, These Are My Words: The Residential School Diary of Violet Pesheens by Ruby Slipperjack
8. In Search of April Raintree by Beatrice Mosionier
9. The Train by Jodie Callaghan, illustrated Georgia Lesley
10. Fatty Legs by Christy Jordan-Fenton & Margaret Pokiak-Fenton, illustrated by Liz Amini-Holmes
11. I Am Not A Number by Jenny Kay Dupuis & Kathy Kacer, illustrated by Gillian Newland
12. When We Were Alone by David A. Robertson, illustrated by Julie Flett
13. A Stranger At Home by Christy Jordan-Fenton & Margaret-Olemaun Pokiak-Fenton, illustrated by Liz Amini-Holmes
14. Porcupines and China Dolls by Robert Arthur Alexie
15. The Marrow Thieves by Cherie Dimaline
16. When I Was Eight by Christy Jordan-Fenton and Margaret Pokiak-Fenton, illustrated by Gabrielle Grimard
17. Stolen Words by Melanie Florence, illustrated by Gabrielle Grimard
18. The Journey Forward by Richard Van Camp & Monique Gray Smith
19. Sugar Falls by David A. Robertson, illustrated by Scott B. Henderson
20. Not My Girl by Christy Jordan-Fenton & Margaret-Olemaun Pokiak-Fenton, illustrated by Gabrielle Grimard
21. As Long as the Rivers Flow by Larry Loyie, with Constance Brissenden, illustrated by Heather Holmlund
22. Five Little Indians by Michelle Good
23. One Story, One Song by Richard Wagamese
24. The Red Files by Lisa Bird-Wilson
25. The Education of Augie Merasty by Joseph Auguste Merasty, with David Carpenter
26. Speaking Our Truth by Monique Gray Smith
27. They Called Me Number One by Bev Sellars
28. I Lost My Talk by Rita Joe & I’m Finding My Talk by Rebecca Thomas, both illustrated by Pauline Young
29. 7 Generations: A Plains Cree Saga by David A. Robertson, illustrated by Scott B. Henderson
30. Amik Loves School by Katherena Vermette, illustrated by Irene Kuziw
31. Up Ghost River by Edmund Metatawabin, with Alexandra Shimo
32. Broken Circle by Theodore Fontaine
33. In My Own Moccasins by Helen Knott
34. The Reason You Walk by Wab Kinew
35. Betty: The Helen Betty Osborne Story by David A. Robertson, illustrated by Scott B. Henderson
36. The Land Is Our Storybook series by Julie-Anne Andre & Mindy Willett

posts.summary: Gabriela Mistral
posts.body:
Gabriela Mistral

Lucila Godoy Alcayaga (1889-1957), pseudonym Gabriela Mistral, was a Chilean diplomat, an educator, an activist, and the first Latin American author to receive a Nobel Prize in Literature.

[Mistral]

Raised in a small village and educated until age 12 by her older sister, Mistral became a teacher’s aid at age 15. Her family was poor and had been abandoned by her father. At 17, she met her first love, who killed himself. Her second love married another woman. She had at least one other love, a woman named Doris Dana, who also kept letters referencing Mistral’s other female partners. [At the end of her life, Dana denied that Mistral had ever had romantic or sexual feelings for any woman.]

Her poetry dealt heavily with death, betrayal, love, and Latin American identity. He tried getting more work as a teacher in underserved, rural areas like the one she had grown up in, but was denied entry to the Normal School due to an objection by the administration. Apparently, Mistral was too in favor of liberalizing education and making it accessible to all social classes, which was an unpopular opinion to the school chaplain.

In 1922, to moved to Mexico to help start a national education system. She also published Desolación (Desolation) in New York, cementing her international fame. In 1925, she represented Latin American in the Institute for Intellectual Cooperation of the League of Nations. It’s remarkable that, despite having no formal education after 12 years old and almost entirely self-taught, that Mistral became a well-known intellectual mind. She advocated for women’s education and continued to write and publish poetry.

[Mistral receiving the Nobel Prize from King Gustav of Sweden]

In 1943, Mistral’s 17-year-old nephew killed himself, and her health was starting to make travel difficult. In 1945, she received the Nobel Prize in Literature for her life’s work. She was the first Latin American and the fifth woman to receive this. When she died, at age 67, of pancreatic cancer, Dana was by her side and Chile went into three days of mourning.

We are guilty of many errors and many faults, but our worst crime is abandoning the children, neglecting the fountain of life. Many of the things we need can wait. The child cannot. Right now is the time his bones are being formed, his blood is being made, and his senses are being developed. To him we cannot answer ‘Tomorrow,’ his name is today.

Su Nombre es Hoy (His Name is Today) by Gabriela Mistral

posts.summary: Jose Maria Morelos
posts.body:
Jose Maria Morelos

José María Teclo Morelos Pérez y Pavón (1765-1815) was a leader in the Mexican War of Independence from Spain. A Roman Catholic priest and a revolutionary, he was responsible for much of the organization surrounding the warfare and the establishment of the independent Congress of Anáhuac.

[a self-portrait of Morelos]

Born in the city now called ‘Morelia’ after him, he worked as a laborer for most of his early life, but wanted to do something beyond working with his hands. He enrolled in college and became ordained as a priest.

The former rector of the college, Father Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla (actually a distant relation of Morelos!), called the town together and urged them to take up arms against Spanish colonial authorities. Hidalgo u Costilla’s army marched on the government and was met with success.

Morelos was determined to join this revolt, and quickly showed a natural affinity for strategy, training, and recruitment. In his first nine months as a military commander, he won 22 victories.

In 1813, Morelos called the National Constituent Congress of Chilpancingo (also called the Congress of Anáhuac) which declared independence and established a Mexican government.

He died 2 years later, captured alone after ordering his men to save themselves. He was tried for treason and sentenced to death by firing squad.

Morelos is a national hero in Mexico. A dedicated anti-colonialist, he also advocated for the abolishment of slavery and racial divisions, and the prohibition of torture and monopolies. He called for the end of the Church’s special privileges and the redistribution of wealth from both the elites and the Church to the poor.

The former rector of the college, Father Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla (actually a distant relation of Morelos!), called the town together and urged them to take up arms against Spanish colonial authorities. Hidalgo u Costilla’s army marched on the government and was met with success.

Morelos was determined to join this revolt, and quickly showed a natural affinity for strategy, training, and recruitment. In his first nine months as a military commander, he won 22 victories.

In 1813, Morelos called the National Constituent Congress of Chilpancingo (also called the Congress of Anáhuac) which declared independence and established a Mexican government.

He died 2 years later, captured alone after ordering his men to save themselves. He was tried for treason and sentenced to death by firing squad.

Morelos is a national hero in Mexico. A dedicated anti-colonialist, he also advocated for the abolishment of slavery and racial divisions, and the prohibition of torture and monopolies. He called for the end of the Church’s special privileges and the redistribution of wealth from both the elites and the Church to the poor.

posts.summary: History They Didn't Teach You In School
posts.body:
History They Didn’t Teach You In School

The Zoot Suit Riots (June 3-8, 1943) were a series of attacks by members of the United States Armed forced against ethnic minorities, almost entirely Mexican American residents in Los Angeles.

Servicemen and White Angelenos attacked over 150 people, including children and teenagers. They were targeted for wearing zoot suits–loose-fitting suits that took up extra fabric during wartime rationing, and were therefore deemed ‘unpatriotic’. Over 500 people were arrested.

The State government of California only became involved and began to carry out an investigation when the Mexican Embassy lodged a formal protest. Most politicians were concerned that these attacks would impede the flow of cheap Mexican agricultural labor California relied upon.

This shows how 'patriotism’ or 'loving America’, especially in wartime, can be an excuse for unchecked racial violence against minorities.

tags: Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair
posts.summary: Pablo Neruda
posts.body:
Pablo Neruda

Born Ricardo Eliécer Neftalí Reyes Basoalto but later known as Pablo Neruda (1904-1973), Neruda was a poet and a diplomat from Chile. He has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature (1971), the Lenin Peace Prize (1953), and the International Peace Prize (1950).

Neruda was born in Parral, Chile, but his mother died when he was only two months old. His father moved the family south to Temuco to remarry, and it was in this blended family that Neruda grew up. He attended the local school headed by Chilean poet Gabriela Mistral (who would become the first Latin American author to win the Nobel Prize in literature) who encouraged his writing.

His father disapproved, so he took the pen name ‘Pablo Neruda’ (he would later change it legally) to avoid his father’s recognition. By age 16, his poems were already published and locally famous, and Neruda moved to Santiago to study French at the Universidad de Chile. He continued writing and publishing poems, and began to receive national and international acclaim.

Neruda was an ardent Communist and Spanish Republican. He worked abroad as a diplomat for Chile. He was elected a Communist Senator, but began getting in trouble as politicians he supported began acting against their previously stated Communist ideals., most notably Chilean President Gabriel González Videla.

His criticism of González Videla resulted in threats of arrest. Neruda went into hiding and escaped first to Argentina, then to Paris, shocking the world (and especially the Chilean government, who insisted he couldn’t possibly have left the country).

Neruda traveled the world until the González Videla government, weakened by corruption scandals, started to fall apart. Neruda returned to Chile to help get Salvador Allende elected president of Chile.

He spent the rest of his life in Chile except for occasional visits outside. He was famous worldwide for his poetry and his politics. He loudly and publically denounced the United States for its actions in the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Vietnam War. He was one of the primary targets of the CIA’s Congress for Cultural Freedom (an anti-communist “advocacy group”).

In 1971, Neruda was awarded the Nobel Prize, though his politics nearly kept him out of the running.

In 1973, Pinochet led a coup d'etat destroying the Popular Unity government and installing himself as a dictator. Neruda was instantly under suspicion and then died, supposedly of a heart attack. However, various reports suggest he was assassinated on Pinochet’s orders. His public funeral was an opportunity for mourners to publically protest the new government despite a massive police presence.

Consider looking for Neruda’s work, such as Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair (1924), which are available for free online in English.

posts.summary: Cauldron from the Hochdorf Chieftain's Grave, a richly-furnished Celtic burial chamber dating from 530 BC in the Hallstatt...
posts.body:
theancientworld:

Cauldron from the Hochdorf Chieftain’s Grave, a richly-furnished Celtic burial chamber dating from 530 BC in the Hallstatt culture period.

The cauldron was imported from Greece and featured handles in the shape of lions.

When one of the handles broke off, the Celts replaced it with a lion of their own crafting.

World History Encyclopedia

posts.summary: Footprints at White Sands National Park
posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Footprints at White Sands National Park

Exciting news! Archaeologists have discovered and accurately dated human footprints in what is now New Mexico that are 23,000 years old. This pushes back confirmed the date of human habitation in the Americas thousands of years–and in particular blows the previously popular “Clovis first theory” out of the water.

The footprints are primarily children and teenagers and were found around tracks of mammoths, giant ground sloths, dire wolves, and birds.

This puts the date of humans in New Mexico as at the height of the Last Glacial Maximum.

For context: other important things that happened around this time include:
-The estimated creation of the Venus of Willendorf figurine (in what is now Austria)
-Humans settled for the first time in Beijing
-The British Isles are covered in ice, they will not be settled by H. sapiens for over ten thousand more years


I also recommend people read “The White Sands discovery only confirmed what Indigenous people have said all along” by Nick Martin, published in HighCountryNews. Link in the reblogs, an excerpt here.

“The academy’s interest in pinpointing the precise time and year that humans first set foot on these lands has drawn an immense amount of funding for digs and field sites, published studies and mainstream news stories, all while failing to even feign the slightest interest or concern for Indigenous people and what we might have to say or think about the ivory tower’s confirmation of our ancestors’ existence. Anyone who read only mainstream coverage would walk away without a clue that this is actually an Indigenous story, not merely a triumphant discovery of capital-s Science. Not a single Indigenous citizen, historian, elder, story-holder, biologist, geneticist or archaeologist was quoted in the piece, nor did the word “Indigenous” or “Native” appear once. This discovery and the knowledge accompanying it, you see, is entirely owned and framed by people who, in the grand scheme of history, have only known this land for a blink of time. Apparently, they can’t help but regard the footprints they discovered, not as Indigenous, but merely as evidence.”

Link to “The White Sands discovery only confirms what Indigenous people have said all along” by Nick Martin

The footprints are primarily children and teenagers and were found around tracks of mammoths, giant ground sloths, dire wolves, and birds.

This puts the date of humans in New Mexico as at the height of the Last Glacial Maximum.

For context: other important things that happened around this time include:
-The estimated creation of the Venus of Willendorf figurine (in what is now Austria)
-Humans settled for the first time in Beijing
-The British Isles are covered in ice, they will not be settled by H. sapiens for over ten thousand more years


I also recommend people read “The White Sands discovery only confirmed what Indigenous people have said all along” by Nick Martin, published in HighCountryNews. Link in the reblogs, an excerpt here.

“The academy’s interest in pinpointing the precise time and year that humans first set foot on these lands has drawn an immense amount of funding for digs and field sites, published studies and mainstream news stories, all while failing to even feign the slightest interest or concern for Indigenous people and what we might have to say or think about the ivory tower’s confirmation of our ancestors’ existence. Anyone who read only mainstream coverage would walk away without a clue that this is actually an Indigenous story, not merely a triumphant discovery of capital-s Science. Not a single Indigenous citizen, historian, elder, story-holder, biologist, geneticist or archaeologist was quoted in the piece, nor did the word “Indigenous” or “Native” appear once. This discovery and the knowledge accompanying it, you see, is entirely owned and framed by people who, in the grand scheme of history, have only known this land for a blink of time. Apparently, they can’t help but regard the footprints they discovered, not as Indigenous, but merely as evidence.”

posts.summary: Wifredo Lam
posts.body:
Wifredo Lam

Today we celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month with Wifredo Lam (1902-1982), a Cuban artist of mixed heritage and a unique, uncategorizable style.

[Lam in front of some of his work]

Lam was born Sagua La Grande, Cuba to a Chinese father and a Congolese-Cuban mulatto mother. He was simultaneously surrounded by Catholic and African religious traditions. In particular, his godmother was a Santería priestess who exposed him to African orishas.

In 1923, Lam was studying painting in Madrid (having left the island to escape the pressure for a law degree). Throughout his time in Europe, he was exposed to a variety of artistic influences, especially Spanish modernism, Surrealism, and the works of Henri Matisse. He also was first exposed to African sculpture here.

During the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War, Lam joined the Republicans and crafted propaganda posters and fought, though he was wounded.

[Untitled (La Brousse), 1598. Mixed media on paper pasted on canvas.]

Lam was friends with many of the great artists of the time, including Matisse, Picasso, Kahlo, and Rivera. He traveled Europe under 1941, when he left for Martinique in the midst of World War II. Here he was imprisoned for 40 days before finally being allowed to return to Cuba.

In Cuba, Lam began to focus on the Afro-Cuban art tradition. He saw that it was degraded and sold for tourists rather than as a true means of artistic expression for an oppressed people. He saw Cuba as in danger of losing its African heritage and felt that freedom from cultural subjugation was as necessary as freedom from political or economic subjugation.

[The Jungle (La Jungla). 1953 Gouache on paper mounted on canvas]

His art underwent a rapid evolution of style, combining Afro-Cuban culture, Surrealism, Cubism, Modernism, and African ideas and values. This was controversial in the art scene and led to rejection by his community from those accusing him of not being truly ‘Cuban’.

Regardless, his art is some of the best known to come out of Cuba, and it speaks to his unique ethnic and educational background, his values, and his sympathies for the common man.

posts.summary: Helen Rodríguez Trías
posts.body:
Helen Rodríguez Trías

A doctor, educator, and women’s rights activist, Helen Rodríguez Trías (1929-2001) was essential in expanding and increasing accessibility to public health services around the world. She was the first Latina director of the American Public Health Association, a founding member of the Women’s Caucus and the Hispanic Caucus of the APHA, and a recipient of the Presidential Citizens Medal.

[Helen Rodríguez Trías]

Born in New York City to Puerto Rican parents, Rodríguez Trías was raised between New York and Puerto Rico. In school, she was placed in a class for students with learning disabilities as a form of racist discrimination before being moved to a class for gifted children due to her intelligence.

Rodríguez Trías returned to Puerto Rico to attend university and medical school at the University of Puerto. Here, she became involved with the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party and became an activist on Puerto Rican independence. She also had four children and received her medical degree in 1960, where she quickly excelled.

Rodríguez Trías established the first center for newborn care in Puerto Rico, which decreased infant mortality by 50% within just 3 years.

She moved back to New York and began working in the Bronx. As the head of the pediatrics department at Lincoln Hospital, Rodríguez Trías lobbied to empower workers in decisions relating to hospital administration. He became involved in the Puerto Rican community. She championed cultural competency in medicine.

[Rodríguez Trías on CSPAN]

While in Puerto Rico, Rodríguez Trías learned that the United States government had been sterilizing Puerto Rican women without consent. She helped found the Committee to End Sterilization Abuse in 1970 and the Women’s Caucus of American Public Health Association in 1971. She fought for the abolishment of enforced sterilization, support abortion, and sought neonatal care. She was the medical director of the New York State Department of Health AIDS Institute, where she focused on minority women.

Her work covered a lot of ground, but it all had the same end goal: increasing options and health for those underserved by the medical system. Rodríguez Trías said,

We need health, but above all we need to create a grounding for healthy public policy that redresses and salvages the growing inequities. We cannot achieve a healthier us without achieving a healthier, more equitable health care system, and ultimately, a more equitable society.

posts.summary: Aimé Césaire
posts.body:
Aimé Césaire

Aimé Fernand David Césaire (1913-2008) was a poet and politician notable for the Négritude movement.

[Césaire]

Born in Basse-Pointe, Martinique, France, a small island in the Caribbean Sea, to lower-class parents who struggled to provide for his education. Césaire, like the rest of Martinique, spoke French but considered himself to be Igbo and a son of Nigeria.

He attended school at the Lycée Louis-le-Grand in Paris on an educational scholarship, where he and two others founded the literary review L'Étudiant noir (The Black Student). This was essential to initiating the Négritude movement.

Négritude (French, a literal translation would be something like ‘Blackness’, and was a reclamation of the derogatory ’nègre’) is a framework of critique developed by francophone intellectuals of the American diaspora during the 1930s. Its goal was to raise a “Black consciousness”. posts.summary: On This Day In History
posts.body:
On This Day In History

September 23rd, 1868 El Grito de Lares (The Lares Revolt) begins in Puerto Rico. It is the first major Puerto Rican revolt against Spanish rule.

posts.summary: Remembering Treasured Chicago Folk Singer Jesus ‘Chuy’ Negrete
posts.body:
kuramirocket:

Remembering Treasured Chicago Folk Singer Jesus ‘Chuy’ Negrete

Imagine having a songwriter accompany you through life — follow you from one country to the next — and sing of your trials and victories, your history. That’s what Jesus “Chuy” Negrete did for Mexican immigrants and their children.

Negrete is being remembered this weekend at the National Museum of Mexican Art. He died May 27 at the age of 72.

The treasured folk singer was dubbed “the Chicano Woody Guthrie,” and for decades the troubadour of Chicago’s barrios and the Chicano movement sang his heart out at protests and picket lines, festivals and Latino studies conferences nationwide.

People who met Negrete never forgot him. His guitar and harmonica were like extensions of his body. He was full of jokes and stories — in Spanish, English and Spanglish — all set to song. His specialty was the corrido, Mexican folk ballads he used to document the Chicano experience and highlight social and political causes.

Negrete frequently talked about the role of the corrido in the Mexican Revolution, how it functioned like a newspaper.

“They used this oral tradition to keep alive their history, and to make political commentary. It was their story, their history books. … The corrido then is to the Chicano — the Mexican American — what the blues is to the Black man” said Negrete.

Negrete’s lyrics were full of Mexican humor and frequently involved foibles around learning English. He poked fun at the powerful and always gave the little guy the last laugh. He could have crowds laughing hysterically, and at the same time deliver biting critiques of cultural imperialism, exploitation of farmworkers or the state of education for Latino youth.

In one of his songs, Negrete tells the story of how teachers changed Mexican students’ names:

If your name was Felipe? Phil! Humberto? Bert. Domingo? Sunday. If your name was Domingo Nieves — Ice Cream Sunday!

Later in the song, Negrete says the nun at “Our Lady of Perpetual Racism” school decides not to shorten his cousin Facundo’s name. “I think we’re going to have to call you Joe,” she says.

Wherever there was a protest, Chuy was there

Negrete lived the experience he sang about. He was born in Mexico. He spent his early years in Texas, where his parents were migrant workers. When he was seven, his family moved to South Chicago for work in the steel mills.

Labor issues — in particular farmworker issues — remained a motivation and theme in his music throughout his life.

“Wherever there was a protest, Chuy would be found there,” said Congressman Jesus “Chuy” Garcia, who knew Negrete for decades. “Whether it was in the back of a pickup truck, in a parking lot. He would be there and he would play his heart out.”

Negrete was brilliantly spontaneous. If he was singing on a picket line, his lyrics would mention strikers right there walking the line. At the Fiesta del Sol, he’d incorporate the señoras making enchiladas into the song. If a kid toddled by, he’d work him in too.

“He would say, ‘Hey mocosito, how are we doing?’” remembered Garcia. “[He’d] play with the kid and then get back to the story that he was telling. He was just able to just pluck people out of their situation, bring them into the song and then go back to the larger storytelling. That was one of his gifts and he was so good and so comfortable at it.”

Negrete grew up hearing the classic Mexican music his dad played when he came home from work at Republic Steel. 

And by his early 20s, he was organizing other young people — including his three younger sisters — into theater and singing troupes that toured the country and highlighted Chicano culture and history.

One of Negrete’s presentations went through 500 years of Chicano history, starting in pre-Hispanic times and running through Mexican independence and the Mexican Revolution.

Using music to educate

Negrete viewed himself as a scholar and an educator. He lectured at universities across the country and was often invited by Latino student groups hungry to learn more about their history and culture.

He believed folk music was integral to political struggle.

“Music is one of the elements that is most utilized by our people,” Negrete told host Linda Fregoso in 1980 on a University of Texas at Austin radio program. “We listen to it, we sing our children to bed with it. Music is a very important element in our cultural world, in our folklore world. So … you utilize the element that is most utilized by the people. … You educate people, they educate themselves. You mix the political with the cultural.”

Negrete was a key part of the Chicano movement nationwide. He worked with Cesar Chavez’s United Farm Workers and the national Farm Labor Organizing Committee.

Negrete’s family saw him straddle two worlds. “Important to a large population, inspiring to a large population — completely unknown to a larger Anglo society,” said Rita Rousseau, Negrete’s wife, who met him in 1988 at the National Museum of Mexican Art’s annual Day of the Dead show, where Negrete was crooning to the crowds looking at the art.

“He’s so beloved within his community and part of so many cultural touchstones and points in history in the United States,” said Negrete’s older son, Joaquin. “He’s the most famous unfamous person.”

Negrete loved to perform. As his health declined over the past few years — and then during the pandemic — he turned to his radio show, Radio Rebelde, which aired on Loyola University’s small station. He broadcast from his dining room table, and of course he wrote corridos about the coronavirus, memorializing essential workers who were disproportionately dying from COVID-19. (Negrete died of congestive heart failure.)

Chicago’s City Council is expected to honor Negrete with a resolution later this month. Negrete’s family is organizing a community celebration of Chuy Negrete this Sunday at the National Museum of Mexican Art. And they’ve been pulling together his many songs, which together document a half century of political struggle and cultural pride for Mexican Americans in Chicago and beyond.

Negrete’s lyrics were full of Mexican humor and frequently involved foibles around learning English. He poked fun at the powerful and always gave the little guy the last laugh. He could have crowds laughing hysterically, and at the same time deliver biting critiques of cultural imperialism, exploitation of farmworkers or the state of education for Latino youth.

In one of his songs, Negrete tells the story of how teachers changed Mexican students’ names:

If your name was Felipe? Phil! Humberto? Bert. Domingo? Sunday. If your name was Domingo Nieves — Ice Cream Sunday!

Later in the song, Negrete says the nun at “Our Lady of Perpetual Racism” school decides not to shorten his cousin Facundo’s name. “I think we’re going to have to call you Joe,” she says.

Wherever there was a protest, Chuy was there

Negrete lived the experience he sang about. He was born in Mexico. He spent his early years in Texas, where his parents were migrant workers. When he was seven, his family moved to South Chicago for work in the steel mills.

Labor issues — in particular farmworker issues — remained a motivation and theme in his music throughout his life.

“Wherever there was a protest, Chuy would be found there,” said Congressman Jesus “Chuy” Garcia, who knew Negrete for decades. “Whether it was in the back of a pickup truck, in a parking lot. He would be there and he would play his heart out.”

Negrete was brilliantly spontaneous. If he was singing on a picket line, his lyrics would mention strikers right there walking the line. At the Fiesta del Sol, he’d incorporate the señoras making enchiladas into the song. If a kid toddled by, he’d work him in too.

“He would say, ‘Hey mocosito, how are we doing?’” remembered Garcia. “[He’d] play with the kid and then get back to the story that he was telling. He was just able to just pluck people out of their situation, bring them into the song and then go back to the larger storytelling. That was one of his gifts and he was so good and so comfortable at it.”

Negrete grew up hearing the classic Mexican music his dad played when he came home from work at Republic Steel. 

And by his early 20s, he was organizing other young people — including his three younger sisters — into theater and singing troupes that toured the country and highlighted Chicano culture and history.

One of Negrete’s presentations went through 500 years of Chicano history, starting in pre-Hispanic times and running through Mexican independence and the Mexican Revolution.

Using music to educate

Negrete viewed himself as a scholar and an educator. He lectured at universities across the country and was often invited by Latino student groups hungry to learn more about their history and culture.

He believed folk music was integral to political struggle.

“Music is one of the elements that is most utilized by our people,” Negrete told host Linda Fregoso in 1980 on a University of Texas at Austin radio program. “We listen to it, we sing our children to bed with it. Music is a very important element in our cultural world, in our folklore world. So … you utilize the element that is most utilized by the people. … You educate people, they educate themselves. You mix the political with the cultural.”

Negrete was a key part of the Chicano movement nationwide. He worked with Cesar Chavez’s United Farm Workers and the national Farm Labor Organizing Committee.

Negrete’s family saw him straddle two worlds. “Important to a large population, inspiring to a large population — completely unknown to a larger Anglo society,” said Rita Rousseau, Negrete’s wife, who met him in 1988 at the National Museum of Mexican Art’s annual Day of the Dead show, where Negrete was crooning to the crowds looking at the art.

“He’s so beloved within his community and part of so many cultural touchstones and points in history in the United States,” said Negrete’s older son, Joaquin. “He’s the most famous unfamous person.”

Negrete loved to perform. As his health declined over the past few years — and then during the pandemic — he turned to his radio show, Radio Rebelde, which aired on Loyola University’s small station. He broadcast from his dining room table, and of course he wrote corridos about the coronavirus, memorializing essential workers who were disproportionately dying from COVID-19. (Negrete died of congestive heart failure.)

Chicago’s City Council is expected to honor Negrete with a resolution later this month. Negrete’s family is organizing a community celebration of Chuy Negrete this Sunday at the National Museum of Mexican Art. And they’ve been pulling together his many songs, which together document a half century of political struggle and cultural pride for Mexican Americans in Chicago and beyond.

posts.summary: Bernardo O'Higgins
posts.body:
Bernardo O'Higgins

One of the founding fathers of modern Chile, Bernardo O'Higgins Riquelme (1778-1842) was a Chilean independence leader.

[Portrait of O'Higgins in the National Congress Library of Chile.]

Born a bastard, he was raised by his mother’s family and was not acknowledged by his father until his father’s death. O'Higgins was educated abroad and became interested in South American independence. He returned to Chile and began to take leadership roles.

On September 18th, 1810, O'Higgins joined the revolt against the French-dominated government. He campaigned for a national congress, and was immediately made deupty of it when it was created.

The Chilean rebels were split into to factions–the pro-independence fighters, including O'Higgins, and those who wanted to return Spanish America to the Spanish throne, away from France. In addition, the pro-independence faction was split into groups among political beliefs, regionality, patronage, and more. The Carrera family was increasingly grabbing power in this messy landscape, and O'Higgins began an ongoing feud with them for power.

O'Higgins also began to grow in military prestige, winning important battles (and not taking much blame for the ones he lost–a privilege of fighting under the leadership of Carreras who took all the heat).

O'Higgins and Carrera fought each other before uniting against royalists, but Carrera failed to show up with reinforcements. O'Higgins went into exile following this defeat, where he met José de San Martín, and Argentine General who helped him fight the royalists.

Fighting continued, both against royalists and fellow pro-independents (Carrera was executed by O'Higgins supporters under questionable circumstances), but eventually O'Higgins ended on top. He rules for six years and established markers, colleges, hospitals, and improved agriculture.

[O'Higgins meets Jose San Martin at the Battle of Maipu 1818.]

He wanted to establish a pure democracy and abolish the nobility, which made him unpopular with other leaders. He offended the church, which in turn alienated the businesspeople, and the government ran bankrupt. A large earthquake in central Chile was devastating, and O'Higgins didn’t have the ability to respond to it.

He was deposed by a coup headed by one of his closest friends and left, joining Simón Bolívar’s nationalist effort for the liberation of Peru.

The Chilean government voted to allow O'Higgins’ return to Chile, but he was too weak to travel. O'Higgins died and was buried in Peru.

Today, he is considered a founding father and one of the most important figures of the South American independence movements.

posts.summary: Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks (1880-1891) by Ilya Repin. Oil on canvas.
posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks (1880-1891) by Ilya Repin. Oil on canvas.

Actually I’m gonna add some context to this one because I love it so much.

Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks to Sultan Mehmed IV of the Ottoman Empire, also known as Cossacks of Saporog Are Drafting a Manifesto is one of the most famous paintings in Russia.

It depicts a scene from Russian history. The Cossacks had defeated the Ottoman Empire in battle, but the emperor demanded they submit anyways. The Cossacks, led by military leader Ivan Sirko, are seen here drafting their reply to this demand.

This reply was insulting, vulgar, and even rhymed in the original Russian. Truly, one of history’s best diss tracks. Iconic.

Zaporozhian Cossacks to the Turkish Sultan!

O sultan, Turkish devil and damned devil’s kith and kin, secretary to Lucifer himself. What the devil kind of knight are thou, that canst not slay a hedgehog with your naked arse? The devil shits, and your army eats. Thou shalt not, thou son of a whore, make subjects of Christian sons. We have no fear of your army; by land and by sea we will battle with thee. Fuck thy mother.

Thou Babylonian scullion, Macedonian wheelwright, brewer of Jerusalem, goat-fucker of Alexandria, swineherd of Greater and Lesser Egypt, pig of Armenia, Podolian thief, catamite of Tartary, hangman of Kamyanets, and fool of all the world and underworld, an idiot before God, grandson of the Serpent, and the crick in our dick. Pig’s snout, mare’s arse, slaughterhouse cur, unchristened brow. Screw thine own mother!

So the Zaporozhians declare, you lowlife. You won’t even be herding pigs for the Christians. Now we’ll conclude, for we don’t know the date and don’t own a calendar; the moon’s in the sky, the year with the Lord. The day’s the same over here as it is over there; for this kiss our arse!

posts.summary: Margo Jones
posts.body:
Margo Jones

A visionary and inspiration, Margaret Virginia “Margo” Jones (1911-1955) was an American stage director and producer who launched the American regional theater movement.

[Jones]

Born in Texas, she traveled and worked through the country and even outside it, going all the way to the Soviet Union for a festival. After finding success in New York City, she returned to Dallas and opened Theatre ‘47 (its name would update every year on New Years’ Eve) in the Magnolia Lounge.

Theatre '47, and Jones’ work there, was groundbreaking in many ways. It was the first modern nonprofit professional resident theater and the first theater-in-the-round. She championed regional theater so the arts would be more accessible.

Her professional work was seminal in the careers of such playwrights as Tennessee Williams, William Inge, Joseph Hayes, Jermone Lawrence, and Robert E. Lee (not the politician).

Called “The Texas Tornado”, Jones lived a short but full life. She revolutionized theater and made it more accessible. An example of an early-20th century woman who succeeded in the private sector and seemed to have full respect of her male peers, it’s impossible to know how different current media culture would be without her contributions.

posts.summary: Cesar Chavez
posts.body:
Cesar Chavez

Today, for Hispanic Heritage Month, we celebrate Cesar Chavez. Chavez is perhaps the most famous labor leader in American history.

[Chavez in 1972]

Born Cesario Estrada Chavez (1927-1993) in Yuma, Arizona to a Mexican American family. At school, he was forbidden from speaking Spanish and forced to change his name to Cesar. His family was not well-off, but largely comfortable, until his grandmother died and the County sold the farmstead.

The Chavez family moved to California during the Great Depression and found work as agricultural laborers. Chavez continued to go to school, where he was bullied for his poverty and faced anti-Latino discrimination. He left education after junior high school and began full time work at age 15.

In 1951, Chavez, at this point married with kids, moved to San Jose and befriended social justice activists Fred Ross and Father Donald McDonnell. Chavez began to be active in social justice initiatives such as voter registration drives and community service with the Community Service Organization (CSO) of San Jose.

As time passed, however, he felt the CSO began to prioritize middle class members over the impoverished and the FBI opened a file on him. He began to work directly with Mexican-American laborers who were being fired so their bosses could illegally hire and exploit cheaper Mexican guest workers. He began a campaign against the Ventura County Farm Labor Association for this, and used sit ins to raise awareness. Chavez and his family (now eight children) moved to Los Angeles where he secured the financial future of the CSO, before resigning in 1962.

In 1962, Chavez and family moved to Delano and began the National Farm Workers Association with his wife Helen Fabela Chavez and activist Dolores Huerta. In 1965, the NFWA made its first big move with the Delano Grape Strike, an act of solidarity between the largely Mexican NFWA members and the mostly Filipino farm workers. It would last for five years, and featured a protest camp including a clinic, nursery, and theater.

[NFWA buttons]

This is a brief introduction to Chavez’ actions and activism. There is certainly more to learn–Chavez led many more strikes and protests, was a pallbearer for Robert Kennedy after his assassination, was investigated by the FBI at least twice more, and helped pass numerous laws. His birthday is a holiday in some states, he is a ‘folk saint’ among some people, and in 1994 he posthumously received the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

posts.summary: Luisa Capetillo
posts.body:
Luisa Capetillo

Today in celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, we take a look at Luisa Capetillo (1879-1922), one of the most famous activists to come out of Puerto Rico. Capetillo was a labor leader, a feminist, and a writer.

[Capetillo]

Born in Arecibo, Puerto Rico and homeschooled, Capetillo found work as a reader. The American Tobacco Company had control over much of the island’s tobacco fields and hired people to read novels to workers. Capetillo read in a tobacco factory, where she began to be involved with labor unions.

In 1904, Capetillo began to write Mi Opinión (My Opinion), essays that were published in radical and union newspapers. She encouraged women to fight for social equality. She touched on the unique experience of Latina women almost a decade before Crenshaw invented the term ‘intersectionality’. She wrote in support of labor unions, anarcism, and against organized religion.

Capetillo helped organize and write for a farm workers’ strike in 1905 and worked as a reporter for the American Federation of Labor. She traveled the island, educating women, and started her own newspaper (La mujer) which centered on women’s issues. She was one of the first Puerto Rican suffragists and campaigned for women’s suffrage in union politics. She organized workers and joined in strikes, and helped pass a minimum-wage law in Puerto Rico.

Capetillo went to jail twice for the crime of wearing pants as a woman.

[Capetillo in men’s clothes]

posts.summary: Diabolito Milano
posts.body:
Diabolito Milano

A 19th-century Cuban pirate captain known for his mixed-race crew and for successfully evading the authorities for over a decade.

Little is known about his early or personal life–Diabolito steadfastly refused contact with any sort of official documentation his entire life. When President Monroe began to fight piracy off the coast of Florida, Diabolito was one of the biggest targets. Known as a particularly violent pirate, he engaged the United States Navy and the Revenue Marine Service multiple times.

His crew, which included “English, Frenchmen, Spaniards, Mulattoes, and Negroes”, was remarkable in his time period. Diabolito and his crew were hunted as fugitives for many years but had no trouble escaping American vessels. It wasn’t until 1823 that the law caught up with them. Many of his men were captured; Diabolito was killed when he refused to surrender.
